newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Asian dynasty-drama unfolds with new HK top judge.
newsitem.headline: Asian dynasty-drama unfolds with new HK top judge.

text.p: An Asian dynasty-drama of wealth and power has unfolded another chapter with the appointment of a low-key lawyer as Hong Kong's first post-colonial top judge
Barrister Andrew Li is scion of one of Hong Kong's most prominent Chinese banking and legal dynasties.
Li, 48, was plucked from outside the judiciary to be Chief Justice under Chinese rule from July 1.

Acclaimed as the right man for a difficult job, he comes from an influential Hong Kong family where success at the top is a standard feature. But he has for years shunned the limelight sought by some of his more extrovert relations.

The modest, some say prim, British-educated lawyer was named on Tuesday by future leader Tung Chee-hwa whose plans to dilute civil liberties have aroused concern with the pro-democracy lobby and Western nations.

In the weeks remaining until the handover of Hong Kong to China at midnight on June 30, Li's primary task is to establish a Court of Final Appeal to replace the British Privy Council as the highest court for the territory's 6.4 million people.

He has the task of ensuring the independence of Hong Kong's judiciary and legal system in the face of doomsayers who see the territory falling prey to "cronyism" from across the border, where "guanxi", using the right connections, is common.
Like his civil servant father, Cambridge-educated Li chose against a career in the banking empire founded by his great-grandfather Li Sek-pang in 1918.
Instead, he entered the complex world of civil law, building a reputation as a cautious and impartial advocate, known for his intellectual rigour and independence.
Li qualified for the British bar in 1970 and became a Queen's Counsel (QC) -- or senior advocate -- in 1988. He has served temporarily as a deputy high court judge.
His reputation for hard work and behind-the-scenes public service caught Governor Chris Patten's eye in 1992.
Patten appointed Li to the most powerful body in colonial Hong Kong -- the Executive Council which serves as the governor's inner cabinet of advisers.
Patten paid tribute to his former adviser and praised Tung's selection of Li who was picked from a list of more than 140 names.
"It is very good news for the rule of law in Hong Kong that such a distinguished lawyer should have been chosen for this post," Patten told Hong Kong radio from London.

Li has had to resign from the Executive Council and give up his stewardship of the influential Hong Kong Jockey Club -- he is an enthusiastic racegoer. He also has to relinquish his British citizenship to comply with post-1997 citizenship qualifications for senior officials.

When China's flag rises over Hong Kong on July 1, Li will step into a post coveted by his father's cousin Simon Li, who in 1971 became the first ethnic Chinese judge in the British dominated judiciary to be appointed to the High Court.
Li senior became the first Chinese justice of appeal in 1984 but was beaten in the race to become the first Chinese Chief Justice by his junior, Ti Liang Yang.
The younger Li will be entitled to move into Yang's former mansion on Victoria Peak which comes complete with floodlit tennis courts, two chefs and four servants.

Li is no stranger to luxury. The Li family bank, the Bank of East Asia run by distant cousin David Li, is the territory's largest Hong Kong-Chinese owned bank with a market value of HK$38 billion (US$4.9 billion).

In addition to banker David Li and former appeal court judge Simon Li, other members of the Li clan include David's brother Arthur, a surgeon and vice chancellor of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, and Simon's lawyer daughter, Gladys, a former chairwoman of the Hong Kong Bar Association.
Hong Kong-born Li is married and has two daughters aged 22 and 19.
